title: Rejection Letter Blues
historical_context: This article reflects the underground culture of the 1990s, particularly within the hacker and phreaker communities, showcasing a blend of humor and critique of mainstream publishing standards.
target_audience: Hackers, writers, and those interested in subversive humor.
short_summary: In 'Rejection Letter Blues,' Jeff Swanson humorously critiques the rejection of his short story by a major science fiction magazine, using exaggerated examples to highlight the absurdity of conventional publishing standards.
summary: In this satirical piece, Jeff Swanson presents a fictional rejection letter from a prominent science fiction magazine, outlining the reasons why his story was deemed unsuitable for publication. Each rule is met with a humorous and absurd example from his narrative, showcasing a blend of outrageous scenarios and irreverent humor. The rejection criteria range from the disapproval of gratuitous violence to the dismissal of pseudo-Medieval fantasy, all while Swanson's writing style remains playful and provocative. The article serves as a commentary on the rigid norms of the literary world, particularly in the genre of speculative fiction, and reflects the broader cultural attitudes of the 1990s hacker community towards mainstream media.
